README: Policy Compliance Audits Take the data from here to build your audit and variable data
READ_MORE: Scraped from an IO scan creation to get the data.  See aws3TL1WFL1Template.json for example use

audits.name: (Upload a custom Adtran AOS audit file)

inputs.name: Logging Server
inputs.hint: The IP address for your organization's logging host. Syslog messages must be sent to this address.

inputs.name: NTP Server
inputs.hint: The IP address or hostname for your organization's NTP Server.

inputs.name: Primary DNS Server
inputs.hint: Primary DNS Server

inputs.name: Secondary DNS Server
inputs.hint: Secondary DNS Server

inputs.name: MOTD Banner
inputs.hint: Enter text for motd banner.

inputs.name: EXEC Banner
inputs.hint: Enter text for exec banner.

inputs.name: Login Banner
inputs.hint: Enter text for login banner.

inputs.name: SYSLOG log level
inputs.hint: SYSLOG log level

inputs.name: Login prompt text
inputs.hint: This is the text displayed to users at the SSH login prompt.

inputs.name: Primary rsyslog server
inputs.hint: IPv4 address of the primary rsyslog server for your organization.

inputs.name: SROS Log Target Index
inputs.hint: The index value for the syslog target on the device.

inputs.name: Primary remote authentication server
inputs.hint: IPv4 address of the primary RADIUS or TACACS+ server for your organization.

inputs.name: Secondary remote authentication server
inputs.hint: IPv4 address of the secondary RADIUS or TACACS+ server for your organization.

inputs.name: Primary NTP server
inputs.hint: IPv4 address of the primary NTP server for your organization.

inputs.name: Secondary NTP server
inputs.hint: IPv4 address of the secondary NTP server for your organization.

inputs.name: NTP Server 1
inputs.hint: The primary NTP server.

inputs.name: NTP Server 2
inputs.hint: The secondary NTP server.

inputs.name: Banner login
inputs.default: You are accessing a U.S. Government \\(USG\\) Information System \\(IS\\) that is provided for USG-authorized use only\.

inputs.name: Primary Gateway
inputs.hint: Enter the primary gateway.

inputs.name: Primary DNS Server
inputs.hint: Enter the primary DNS server.

inputs.name: Alternate DNS Server
inputs.hint: Enter the alternate DNS server.

inputs.name: ADN Primary Manager
inputs.hint: Enter the IP of the primary ADN managing device, or 'self' if no centralized management.

inputs.name: Syslog Server
inputs.hint: Enter the domain name or IP of the syslog server for log notifications.

inputs.name: Internal Networks
inputs.hint: Enter a pipe seperated list of internal networks/netmask in CIDR format.

inputs.name: SNMP Community
inputs.hint: Enter a name of the SNMP read only community in your environment.

audits.name: TNS BlueCoat ProxySG Benchmark
(Upload a custom Brocade FabricOS audit file)

inputs.name: SYSLOG server IP
inputs.hint: The IP address of a trusted syslog daemon server for your organization.

inputs.name: NTP server IP
inputs.hint: The IP address of a trusted NTP server for your organization. The default value is LOCL.

inputs.name: SCP server IP
inputs.hint: The IP address of a trusted SCP server for your organization.

inputs.name: SNMPv3 trap target
inputs.hint: SNMPv3 IP address of traps, to add more replace 0 with 1,2 or 3 etc.

audits.name: CIS Cisco IOS 12 L1 v4.0.0

inputs.name: Authentication key ID for NTP servs
inputs.hint: This key should be used to authenticate communications with the routers NTP servers

inputs.name: NTP server IP address
inputs.hint: Your organization's preferred NTP server

inputs.name: AG ingress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The number of the access control list on the perimeter router's external interface used to block internal source addresses.

inputs.name: Internal IP address and netmask
inputs.hint: Your organization's internal IP address range, defined by an IP address and network mask. This network is used in the TCP intercept ACL and in the AG ingress ACL to block spoofed addresses.

inputs.name: External interface name
inputs.hint: The external interface for your organization.

inputs.name: Keychain name
inputs.hint: The keychain name for your organization's routing protocol.

inputs.name: Internal Network ingress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The number of the access control list used to allow internal source addresses to enter the external interface.

inputs.name: AS Number
inputs.hint: The Autonomous System number used by the router

inputs.name: OSPF Key ID
inputs.hint: Your organization's OSPF key ID

inputs.name: RIPv2 keychain name
inputs.hint: The keychain for your organization's RIPv2 authentication. Leave blank if this keychain type is not used.

inputs.name: RIPv2 key number
inputs.hint: The key number for your organization's RIPv2 authentication. Leave blank if this keychain type is not used.

inputs.name: Inside_Interface
inputs.hint: This is the inside interface for the device in your organization.

inputs.name: NAMEIF_Inside
inputs.hint: This is the name of inside interface for the device in your organization.

inputs.name: Inside_Network
inputs.hint: This is the network IP address and subnet mask of the Inside interface for your organization.

inputs.name: Outside_Interface
inputs.hint: This is the outside interface for the device in your organization.

inputs.name: NAMEIF_Outside
inputs.hint: This is the name of outside interface for the device in your organization.

inputs.name: MGMT_Interface
inputs.hint: This is the out of bounds management interface for the device in your organization.

inputs.name: NAMEIF_Mgmt
inputs.hint: This is the name of the out of bounds management interface for the device in your organization.

inputs.name: Inside_Access_In_ACL
inputs.hint: This is the ACL applied to the Inside interface to inspect inbound traffic.

inputs.name: Inside_Acc_Out_ACL
inputs.hint: This is the ACL applied to the Inside interface to inspect outbound traffic.

inputs.name: Outside_Acc_In_ACL
inputs.hint: This is the ACL applied to the Outside interface to inspect inbound traffic.

inputs.name: Outside_Acc_Out_ACL
inputs.hint: This is the ACL applied to the Outside interface to inspect outbound traffic.

inputs.name: MGMT_Access_In_ACL
inputs.hint: This is the ACL applied to the Management interface to inspect inbound traffic.

inputs.name: MGMT_Access_Out_ACL
inputs.hint: This is the ACL applied to the Management interface to inspect outbound traffic.

inputs.name: Syslog_Server
inputs.hint: This is the IP address for the off device syslog storage server for your organization.

inputs.name: IPv4 Loopback Addr
inputs.hint: This is the IP loopback address range as defined by IANA.

inputs.name: AAA Server Group
inputs.hint: This is the configured server group name defining AAA services in your organization.

inputs.name: AAA_Server_1
inputs.hint: This is the first configured AAA server for your organization.

inputs.name: AAA_Server_2
inputs.hint: This is the second configured AAA server for your organization.

inputs.name: Emergency_Account
inputs.hint: This is the name of the single account created on your device for emergency purposes when utilizing AAA services.

inputs.name: NTP_Server_1
inputs.hint: This is the IP address of the 1st NTP server utilized by your organization.

inputs.name: NTP_Server_2
inputs.hint: This is the IP address of the 2nd NTP server utilized by your organization.

inputs.name: NTP_Auth_Key
inputs.hint: This is the number of the NTP authentication-key utilized in your organization.

inputs.name: DNS_Server_1
inputs.hint: This is the IP address of the 1st DNS name-server utilized in your organization.

inputs.name: DNS_Server_2
inputs.hint: This is the IP address of the 2nd DNS name-server utilized in your organization.

inputs.name: DNS_Server_Group
inputs.hint: This is the name of the DNS server-group utilized in your organization.

inputs.name: SNMP_Host_IP
inputs.hint: The IP address for an authorized SNMP host from with your management network range.

inputs.name: Class_Map
inputs.hint: This is the class map name used for the TCP timeout policy in your organization.

inputs.name: Policy_Map
inputs.hint: This is the policy map name used for the TCP timeout policy in your organization.

inputs.name: Service_Policy_TCP
inputs.hint: This is the service policy name used for the TCP timeout policy in your organization.

inputs.name: Crypto_Map_Name
inputs.hint: This is the crypto map utilized to build the IPSec site-to-site VPN for securing OOBM management traffic.

inputs.name: IPSec_ACL
inputs.hint: This is the ACL used by the IPSec site-to-site VPN to restrict access to and from the tunnel for OOBM management traffic.

inputs.name: OOBM_IP_Subnet
inputs.hint: The management interface IP address and subnet mask from your organization's managed network address space.

inputs.name: OOBM_Network
inputs.hint: The management network IP address and subnet mask from your organization's managed network address space.

inputs.name: OOBM_Mgmt_Network
inputs.hint: The network address and subnet for the authorized network range from which the device is being managed.

inputs.name: Inside_Next_Hop
inputs.hint: The IP address of the next-hop router associated with the Inside interface.

inputs.name: SNMP_V3_Group
inputs.hint: This is the name for the SNMP V3 group used on your device.

inputs.name: Transform_Name
inputs.hint: This is the name of the transform-set used in your organization's IPSec tunnel for OOBM management traffic.

inputs.name: SSH Algorithm MAC
inputs.hint: The list of SSH algorithm MAC types

inputs.name: SSH Algorithm Encryption
inputs.hint: The list of SSH algorithm encryption types

audits.name: DISA STIG Cisco Firewall v8r25

inputs.name: IS-IS keychain name
inputs.hint: The keychain for your organization's IS-IS authentication. Leave blank if this keychain type is not used.

inputs.name: EIGRP keychain
inputs.hint: The keychain for your organization's EIGRP authentication. Leave blank if this keychain type is not used.

inputs.name: RIPv2 keychain
inputs.hint: The keychain for your organization's RIPv2 authentication. Leave blank if this keychain type is not used.

inputs.name: Routing Protocol Key Chain Name
inputs.hint: The key chain name for your organization's routing protocol.

inputs.name: Emergency account
inputs.hint: The username of the emergency account configured for your organization. The credentials for this account must be stored ina locked safe.

inputs.name: NTP server address 1
inputs.hint: The IP address of the first NTP server listed for your organization.

inputs.name: NTP server address 2
inputs.hint: The IP address of the second NTP server listed for your organization.

inputs.name: NTP multicast address 1
inputs.hint: The IP address of the first NTP multicast address listed for your organization.

inputs.name: NTP multicast address 2
inputs.hint: The IP address of the second NTP multicast address listed for your organization.

inputs.name: NMS ACL - ACL ID
inputs.hint: The ACL list number for your organization's network management system SNMP ACL.

inputs.name: NMS ACL - authorized host address
inputs.hint: The IP address of the permitted host for network management system SNMP requests.

inputs.name: Internal interface
inputs.hint: The name of the internal interface for your organization.

inputs.name: Control plane service policy
inputs.hint: The name of your organization's control-plane service policy. This policy is designed to mitigate DoS attacks but requires preparation. For more information see result NET0966 - Control plan protection is not enabled.

inputs.name: IP receive ACL ID
inputs.hint: The access control list number for IP receive filtering. This should be used if if Control Plane is not in use. Review the ACL list to ensure it is configured correctly to filter traffic.

inputs.name: OOBM egress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The access control list number for egress through the out of band management (OOBM) interface. This interface grants the management network access to the router.

inputs.name: OOBM interface
inputs.hint: The OOBM interface name. It is used for VPN connectivity. The management network must be restricted to accessing this interface or information from the managed network will leak.

inputs.name: Management network
inputs.hint: The local management network address and wildcard mask. Access to this network through the out of band management (OOBM) interface must be restricted to the remote management network (e.g. NOC).

inputs.name: Remote management network
inputs.hint: The remote management network range (such as the NOC's range). This range must be granted access through the out of band management (OOBM) interface.

inputs.name: OOBM ingress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The access control list number for ingress through the out of band management (OOBM) interface. This interface grants the management network access to the router.

inputs.name: Management interface
inputs.hint: The name of the management interface for your organization.

inputs.name: Management interface network
inputs.hint: The IP address and network mask of the router's management interface.

inputs.name: Management ingress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The ingress access control list for blocking your organization's non-management traffic from your management network.

inputs.name: Management egress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The egress access control list for blocking your organization's management traffic from your non-management network.

inputs.name: OOBM filtering route-map
inputs.hint: The policy name for your organization's local OOBM filtering route-map.

inputs.name: NIPRNet link interface
inputs.hint: The name of the router's interface that connects to the NIPRNET Provider.

inputs.name: In-band management VPN
inputs.hint: The VPN crypto map name for in-band management of the device.

inputs.name: In-band management ACL ID
inputs.hint: The number of the access control list filtering VPN access for in-band management of the device.

inputs.name: Management traffic class-map
inputs.hint: The name for your organization's class-map name for management traffic.

inputs.name: Management traffic class ACL
inputs.hint: The extended access control list name classifying your organization's management traffic. It must permit any address to connect to the local management network.

inputs.name: Management traffic policy-map
inputs.hint: The name for your organization's policy-map name for the management traffic.

inputs.name: Management traffic DSCP value
inputs.hint: The DSCP value for your organization's management traffic.

inputs.name: Syslog host address
inputs.hint: The IP address for your organization's logging host. Syslog messages must be sent to this address.

inputs.name: AAA login group
inputs.hint: The TACACS+ or RADIUS group configured on the device. This group is allowed to authenticate through http, con, and vty interfaces.

inputs.name: VTY authorized network
inputs.hint: The individual IP address or network address and wildcard mask that are allowed to access the router through VTY.

inputs.name: VTY ACL ID
inputs.hint: The access control list number restricting VTY access.

inputs.name: OOOBM VPN crypto map
inputs.hint: The VPN crypto map name for out-of-band management of the device.

inputs.name: OOBM VPN ACL ID
inputs.hint: The number of the access control list filtering VPN access for out-of-band management of the device.

inputs.name: IPv6 egress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The access control list number for IPv6 outbound connection filtering.

inputs.name: IPv6 backbone ACL ID
inputs.hint: The access control list number for IPv6 outbound to backbone connection filtering.

inputs.name: Tunnel Source Interface
inputs.hint: The source interface of the 6to4 tunnel interface.

inputs.name: IPv4 egress ACL ID
inputs.hint: The access control list number for IPv4 outbound connection filtering.

inputs.name: IPv4 6to4 address
inputs.hint: The hexadecimal representation of the IPv4 address of the internal network interface.

inputs.name: IP PIM-enabled interface
inputs.hint: IP interface with PIM enabled.

inputs.name: IP standard access-list
inputs.hint: The standard access-list used for filtering authorized PIM neighbors.

inputs.name: IPV6 PIM access-list
inputs.hint: The IPv6 access-list used for filtering authorized PIM neighbors.

inputs.name: Standard IP access-list multicast
inputs.hint: The filter used to effect multicast traffic outside of the administratively scoped IPv4 multicast space.

inputs.name: Switch Port Management Interface
inputs.hint: The management interface port for your organization.

inputs.name: Management VLAN Identification
inputs.hint: The management vlan configured for your organization's mangement network element's OOBM interface.

inputs.name: OOBM Switch Trunk Port
inputs.hint: The device's trunk listening interface.

inputs.name: Permitted Non-OOBM VLANs
inputs.hint: The vlans that are allowed on the trunk interface excluding the management vlan.

inputs.name: Layer 3 MGMT VLAN Interface
inputs.hint: The VLAN interface configured to carry the management network traffic.

inputs.name: MGMT VLAN Access-List
inputs.hint: The MGMT access-list configured to control management traffic.

inputs.name: SSH Algorithm MAC
inputs.hint: The list of SSH algorithm MAC types

inputs.name: SSH Algorithm Encryption
inputs.hint: The list of SSH algorithm encryption types

inputs.name: Banner displayed at login
inputs.default: I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.
inputs.hint: Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner

inputs.hint: Define the delay time after each failed login attempt in seconds. The delay increases by this value for each subsequent login attempt after the value specified in the backoff-threshold option. The range is from 5 through 10. The default is 5.

inputs.name: Limit number of user authenticate attempts
inputs.hint: Limit the maximum number of times a user is allowed to attempt to authenticate with the wrong password before the connection is terminated. The range is from 1 through 10. The system default is 10.

inputs.name: Minimum length of password attempt
inputs.hint: Limit the minimum length of time in seconds that the connection remains open while the user is attempting to enter a password to log in. The range is from 20 through 60. The default setting is 20.

inputs.name: Maximum length of password attempt
inputs.hint: Limit the maximum length of time in seconds available for a user to enter a username and password before the connection is terminated. The range is from 20 through 30 with a default of 120.

inputs.name: Length of lockout.
inputs.hint: Set the amount of time in minutes before a user can attempt to login after being locked out due to the number of failed login attempts specified in Step 1 with the tries-before-disconnect statement. The range is from 1 through 43200 with a default of 120.

inputs.name: NFS Kerberos realm
inputs.hint: The name of the Kerberos realm used for NFS authentication.

inputs.name: NFS simultaneous security contexts
inputs.hint: The number of security contexts (RPCSEC_GSS sessions) created before they are reused. The expected number for this option is in hundreds or thousands.

inputs.name: NFS idle context timeout
inputs.hint: The length of time to maintain idle security contexts. The default of 6 minutes should be acceptable in most cases.

inputs.name: NFS default security style
inputs.hint: The default security style assigned to new volumes or qtrees. Acceptable values are unix, ntfs, and mixed.

inputs.name: NFS default unix user
inputs.hint: If the unix or mixed security styles are in use this is the Unix user Windows users will be mapped to.

inputs.name: NFS default Windows user
inputs.hint: If the ntfs or mixed security styles are in use this is the Windows user Unix users will be mapped to.

inputs.name: NFS user mapping expiration
inputs.hint: The number of minutes Windows to Unix mappings will remain in cache.

inputs.hint: The path to the config for the Apache server.  Defaults to /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf or /etc/apache2/apache2.conf depending on OS.

inputs.hint: The UID must be  less than the UID_MIN value in /etc/login.defs.

inputs.name: Account GID for Apache
inputs.hint: The GID must be  less than the GID_MIN value in /etc/login.defs.

inputs.hint: The groups id must be less than the UID_MIN value in /etc/login.defs.

inputs.hint: The path to the Apache installation.

inputs.hint: Must be owned by root and have a group ownership of the Apache group.

inputs.hint: The path Apache tries to switch to before the core is dumped for debugging.

inputs.name: Lock file directory
inputs.hint: The path to the lock file used when Apache uses fcntl(2) or flock(2) system calls to implement a mutex.

inputs.name: PID file path
inputs.hint: The path to the process ID file to which the server records the process ID of the server

inputs.name: Scoreboard directory
inputs.hint: The path which the server will use for inter-process communication (IPC) among the Apache processes.

inputs.name: Apache Document Root directories
inputs.hint: The path which for Apache Document Root directories.

inputs.name: Web content directory
inputs.hint: An escaped path that contains web content to be served by Apache. In httpd.conf it must be configured with 'Deny from all' and a limited 'Allow from' network.

inputs.name: Require directives
inputs.hint: Include the appropriate Require directives, with values that are appropriate for the purposes of the directory.

inputs.name: Allow directive
inputs.hint: Include the appropriate Allow and Deny directives, with values that are appropriate for the purposes of the directory.

inputs.name: Deny directive
inputs.hint: Include the appropriate Allow and Deny directives, with values that are appropriate for the purposes of the directory.

inputs.name: Prohibited default web handler
inputs.hint: The name of a handler containing default content that is not needed or appropriate for production use. While present in a default Apache installation, this content must be #removed.

inputs.name: CGI-BIN directory
inputs.hint: The CGI-BIN path containing default CGI content, such as printenv and test-cgi.

inputs.name: Error log path
inputs.hint: The path to the ErrorLog file where Apache will store error logs, configured in httpd.conf.

inputs.name: Custom log path
inputs.hint: The path to the CustomLog file.

inputs.name: SSL certificate path
inputs.hint: The path to the SSL certificate used by Apache.

inputs.name: SSL key file path
inputs.hint: The path to the SSL certificate used by Apache.

inputs.hint: The full path for the BIN folder for executables with no trailing slash.

inputs.name: DB2 Owner Username
inputs.hint: The user name for the DB2 instance being audited.

inputs.name: DB2 Group Name
inputs.hint: The group name for the DB2 instance being audited.

inputs.hint: The full path for database instance.  Most uses include using the sqllib/bin path.

audits.name: CIS IBM DB2 9 Benchmark v3.0.1 Level 2 OS Linux

inputs.name: DB2 Version
inputs.hint: This is your IBM DB2 version.

inputs.name: sqllib Directory
inputs.hint: This is the path to the sqllib directory.

inputs.name: DB2 Container Dir
inputs.hint: This is the path to the DB2 container directory.

inputs.name: DB2 User
inputs.hint: This is the DB2 user account.

inputs.name: DB2 Group
inputs.hint: This is the DB2 group name.

inputs.name: Default DB Path
inputs.hint: This is the default DB path.

inputs.name: Database Name
inputs.hint: This is the name of the database being audited.

inputs.name: Primary Archive Log
inputs.hint: This is the primary destination for archived log files defined in logarchmeth1 value.

inputs.name: Sec Archive Log
inputs.hint: This is the secondary destination for archived log files defined in logarchmeth2 value.

inputs.name: Archive Log Fail
inputs.hint: This is the destinations where DB2 will try to archive log files due to a media problem with the other locations.

audits.name: CIS IBM DB2 OS L2 v1.2.0

inputs.name: Internal IP network
inputs.hint: Your organization's internal IP address range.

inputs.name: DNSSEC Key Path
inputs.hint: This is the full path to the dnssec .key file used by your organization.

inputs.name: DNSSEC Private Path
inputs.hint: This is the full path to the dnssec .private file used by your organization.

inputs.name: TSIG Key 1 Path
inputs.hint: This is the full path to the first TSIG key included in named.conf.

inputs.name: TSIG Key 2 Path
inputs.hint: This is the full path to the second TSIG key included in named.conf.

inputs.name: Zone Transfer Server 1
inputs.hint: This is the zone transfer server associated with TSIG Key 1 included in named.conf.

inputs.name: Zone Transfer Server 2
inputs.hint: This is the zone transfer server associated with TSIG Key 2 included in named.conf.

inputs.name: TSIG Key 1 Name
inputs.hint: This is name of the first TSIG key in named.conf and associated with Zone Transfer Server 1.

inputs.name: TSIG Key 2 Name
inputs.hint: This is name of the second TSIG key in named.conf and associated with Zone Transfer Server 2.

inputs.name: Zone TSIG Key
inputs.hint: This is TSIG key associated with the transfer zone.

inputs.name: Transfer Zone Name
inputs.hint: This is name of the transfer zone.

inputs.name: GSS-TSIG Credential
inputs.hint: This is the tkey-gssapi-credential value which should be used in the options section of named.conf.

inputs.name: GSS-TSIG Domain
inputs.hint: This is the tkey-domain value which should be used in the options section of named.conf.

inputs.name: GSS Key Name
inputs.hint: This is the GSS key name which should be used to define the algorithm in named.conf.

inputs.name: GSS Secret Key Name
inputs.hint: This is the GSS secret key name which should be used to define the key in named.conf.

inputs.name: DHCID Key Path
inputs.hint: This is the full path to the DHCID TSIG key which should be defined in named.conf.

inputs.name: DNSSEC Key Name
inputs.hint: This is the name of the dnssec .key file used by your organization.

inputs.name: Blackhole Addresses
inputs.hint: This is the list of all private RFC 1918 addresses not in use by your organization.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:
-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.
-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.
-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.
-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.
-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.

inputs.name: Owner should be the SA or Web Manager account
inputs.hint: If root or an authorized user does not own the web system files and the permission are not correct, this is a finding.

inputs.name: WebAmins group
inputs.hint: If used, the WebAmins group should contain only accounts of persons authorized to manage the web server configuration.

inputs.name: Apache directory
inputs.hint: Apache directory and file permissions and ownership should be set to the proper configuration.

inputs.name: CGI-BIN directory
inputs.hint: The CGI-BIN path containing default CGI content, such as printenv and test-cgi.

inputs.name: Apache bin directory
inputs.hint: The Apache bin path containing web server system configurations.

inputs.name: Apache configuration directory
inputs.hint: The Apache bin path containing apache system configurations including httpd.conf.

inputs.name: Apache htdocs directory
inputs.hint: Location of the document root directory.

inputs.name: Apache logs directory
inputs.hint: Directory where Apache log files can be found.

inputs.name: PID file path
inputs.hint: The path to the process ID file to which the server records the process ID of the server

inputs.name: Scoreboard directory
inputs.hint: The path which the server will use for inter-process communication (IPC) among the Apache processes.

inputs.name: ScriptAlias directive controls
inputs.hint: The ScriptAlias directive controls which directories the Apache server sees as containing scripts.

inputs.name: Web content directory
inputs.hint: A path that contains web content to be served by Apache. In httpd.conf it must be configured with 'Deny from all' and a limited 'Allow from' network.

inputs.name: Directory that forms the main document tree visible from the web
inputs.hint: This directive controls whether the httpd may use memory-mapping if it needs to read the contents of a file during delivery.

inputs.name: LimitRequestFieldSize
inputs.hint: To view the LimitRequestFieldSize value search httpd.conf

inputs.name: LimitRequestLine
inputs.hint: To view the LimitRequestLine value search httpd.conf

inputs.name: .htaccess directory
inputs.hint: Use the command find / -name httpd.conf to find the file.

inputs.hint: The name of the group with permissions to run Apache.

inputs.name: httpd conf directory

inputs.hint: Directory where Apache log files can be found.

inputs.name: Maps URLs to filesystem locations
inputs.hint: The Alias directive allows documents to be stored in the local filesystem other than under the DocumentRoot.

inputs.name: Maps a URL to a filesystem location and designates as CGI script
inputs.hint: The ScriptAlias marks the target directory as containing CGI scripts that will be processed by mod_cgi's cgi-script handler.

inputs.name: Maps a URL to a filesystem location using a regular expression
inputs.hint: This directive is equivalent to ScriptAlias, but makes use of regular expressions, instead of simple prefix matching.

inputs.name: Directory that forms the main document tree visible from the web
inputs.hint: This directive controls whether the httpd may use memory-mapping if it needs to read the contents of a file during delivery.

inputs.hint: Insert installed organization anti-virus software

inputs.name: Log format string
inputs.hint: The string defining the format of each line in Apache log files.

By using this IS \(which includes any device attached to this IS\), you consent to the following conditions: -The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct \(PM\), law enforcement \(LE\), and counterintelligence \(CI\) investigations. -At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS. -Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose. -This IS includes security measures \(e.g., authentication and access controls\) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy. -Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.

inputs.name: VMWare tools version(s)
inputs.hint: The allowed versions of VMWare tools installed on guests.

inputs.name: VMWare tools update policy
inputs.hint: Controls when tools will be updated. Possible values are Manual or Automatic.

inputs.name: VMWare tools synchronization policy
inputs.hint: Controls whether guest clocks are synchronized with the host clock.

inputs.name: VMWare tools acceleration policy
inputs.hint: Controls whether VMWare tools will enable video acceleration.

inputs.name: VMWare tools logging policy
inputs.hint: Controls whether VMWare tools logging is enabled in the guest.

inputs.name: VMWare tools memory hot-add policy
inputs.hint: Controls whether you can add memory to a guest while it is powered on.

inputs.name: VMWare tools CPU hot-add policy
inputs.hint: Controls whether you can add CPU resources to a guest while it is powered on.

inputs.name: VMWare tools boot delay
inputs.hint: The number of seconds guest boot up will be delayed.

inputs.name: VMSafe agent address
inputs.hint: The IP address of the VMSafe agent security VM. The VMsafe CPU/memory API allows a security virtual machine to inspect and modify the contents of the memory and CPU registers on other VMs, for the purpose of detecting and preventing malware attacks.

inputs.name: VMSafe agent port number
inputs.hint: The VMsafe CPU/memory API allows a security virtual machine to inspect and modify the contents of the memory and CPU registers on other VMs, for the purpose of detecting and preventing malware attacks.

inputs.name: Maximum VMs
inputs.hint: The maximum number of guests the host is configured to allow.

inputs.name: Maximum running VMs
inputs.hint: The maximum number of running guests the host is configured to allow.

inputs.name: Maximum VCPUs
inputs.hint: The maximum number of virtual VPUs the host is configured to allow.

inputs.name: esxAdminsGroup AD check interval
inputs.hint: Interval between checks for whether the group specified by 'esxAdminsGroup' has appeared in Active Directory, in minutes.

inputs.name: SSH session timeout
inputs.hint: The number of minutes before an idle SSH session will be disconnected.

inputs.name: SSH service timeout
inputs.hint: The number of minutes that can elapse before you must log in after the ESXi Shell is enabled. After the timeout period if you have not logged in the shell is disabled.

inputs.name: Global log level
inputs.hint: Controls the global log level. Valid values are: none, quiet, panic, error, warning, info, verbose and trivia.

inputs.name: Remote syslog address
inputs.hint: The IP address of the centralized syslog server for your organization.

inputs.name: Fault tolerance log timeout
inputs.hint: Time in milliseconds to wait on FT log socket.

inputs.name: Fault tolerance extra log timeout
inputs.hint: Time in milliseconds for temporary increase in fault tolerance timeout

inputs.name: System log rotation count
inputs.hint: Default number of rotated logs to keep. Reset to default on zero.

inputs.name: System log rotation size
inputs.hint: Default size of logs before rotation, in KiB. Reset to default on zero.

inputs.name: System log directory
inputs.hint: The path to the system log directory.

inputs.name: NTP server address
inputs.hint: The name or IP address of the NTP server for your organization.

inputs.name: NFS heartbeat frequency
inputs.hint: Time in seconds between NFS heartbeats.

inputs.name: NFS heartbeat timeout
inputs.hint: Time in seconds before aborting a heartbeat request.

inputs.name: NFS heartbeat delta
inputs.hint: Time in seconds after a successful GETATTR request before the heartbeat world issues a heartbeat request for a volume. If an NFS volume is in an unavailable state, an update is sent every time the heartbeat world runs (NFS.HeartbeatFrequency seconds).

inputs.name: NFS heartbeat maximum failures
inputs.hint: The number of consecutive heartbeat requests that must fail before the server is marked as unavailable.

inputs.name: FT heartbeat maximum failures
inputs.hint: Number of failed heartbeats before declaring FT host dead.

inputs.name: FT heartbeat timeout
inputs.hint: Time in milliseconds before declaring a fault tolerant host dead.

inputs.name: FT primary connection timeout
inputs.hint: Time in milliseconds to wait when connecting to the primary.

inputs.name: FT backup connection timeout
inputs.hint: Time in milliseconds to wait when connecting to the backup.

inputs.name: CPU heartbeat timeout
inputs.hint: Time in seconds before sending NMI to a locked CPU.

inputs.name: CPU heartbeat interval
inputs.hint: Interval to check CPU lockups.

inputs.name: CPU panic timeout
inputs.hint: Interval in seconds after which to panic if no heartbeats received.

inputs.name: NFS IP address connections
inputs.hint: Maximum number of NFS connections per IP address.

inputs.name: Deny log on through Terminal Services
inputs.hint: Any account with the right to log on through Terminal Services could be used to log on to the remote console of the computer. If this user right is not restricted to legitimate users who need to log on to the console of the computer, unauthorized users might download and run malicious software that elevates their privileges.

inputs.name: Log on as a service user right
inputs.hint: This policy setting allows accounts to launch network services or to register a process as a service running on the system. This user right should be restricted on any computer in a high security environment, but because many applications may require this privilege, it should be carefully evaluated and tested before configuring it in an enterprise environment.

inputs.name: Log on as a batch job
inputs.hint: This policy setting allows accounts to log on using the task scheduler service.

inputs.name: Configure 'Deny log on as a service'
inputs.hint: This security setting determines which service accounts are prevented from registering a process as a service. This policy setting supersedes the Log on as a service policy setting if an account is subject to both policies

inputs.name: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether to audit the use of all user privileges, including Backup and Restore, when the Audit privilege use setting is in effect. If you enable both policies, an audit event will be generated for every file that is backed up or restored. If the Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege setting is enabled, a very large number of security events could quickly fill the Security event log.

inputs.name: FIPS compliant algorithms
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether the Transport Layer Security/Secure Sockets Layer (TLS/SSL) Security Provider supports only the TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA cipher suite.

inputs.name: server operators schedule tasks
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether members of the Server Operators group are allowed to submit jobs by means of the AT schedule facility. The impact of this policy setting configuration should be small for most organizations. Users, including those in the Server Operators group, will still be able to create jobs by means of the Task Scheduler Wizard, but those jobs will run in the context of the account with which the user authenticates when they set up the job.

inputs.name: Disable save PW
inputs.hint: Prevent the dial-up password from being saved

inputs.name: Audit access of global system objects
inputs.hint: This policy setting creates a default system access control list (SACL) for system objects such as mutexes (mutual exclusive), events, semaphores, and MS-DOS devices, and causes access to these system objects to be audited. If the Audit: Audit the access of global system objects setting is enabled, a very large number of security events could quickly fill the Security event log.

inputs.name: Named Pipes that can be accessed anonymously
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines which communication sessions, or pipes, will have attributes and permissions that allow anonymous access. Note: When you configure this setting you specify a list of one or more objects. The delimiter used when entering the list is a line feed or carriage return, that is, type the first object on the list, press the Enter button, type the next object, press Enter again, etc. The setting value is stored as a comma-delimited list in group policy security templates. It is also rendered as a comma-delimited list in Group Policy Editor's display pane and the Resultant Set of Policy console. It is recorded in the registry as a line-feed delimited list in a REG_MULTI_SZ value.

inputs.name: TcpMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions
inputs.hint: This entry appears as MSS: (TcpMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions) SYN-ACK retransmissions when a connection request is not acknowledged in the SCE. This entry determines the number of times that TCP retransmits a SYN before it aborts the attempt. The retransmission time-out is doubled with each successive retransmission in a given connect attempt. The initial time-out value is three seconds.

inputs.name: enableforcedlogoff
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether to disconnect users who are connected to the local computer outside their user account's valid logon hours. It affects the SMB component. If you enable this policy setting, client sessions with the SMB service will be forcibly disconnected when the client's logon hours expire. If you disable this policy setting, established client sessions will be maintained after the client's logon hours expire. If you enable this policy setting you should also enable Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire. If your organization configures logon hours for users, it makes sense to enable this policy setting.

inputs.name: Recovery console
inputs.hint: Configure 'Recovery console: Allow floppy copy and access to all drives and all folders

inputs.name: Logon Window Caption
inputs.hint: This is the window caption text for the login warning a user receives when logging onto the system.

inputs.name: Logon Window Text
inputs.default: All activities performed on this system will be monitored.
inputs.hint: This is the window text for the login warning a user receives when logging onto the system.

inputs.name: logon: Require smart card
inputs.hint: Configure 'Interactive logon: Require smart card' (Not Scored)

inputs.name: Allow system to be shut down without having to log on
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether a computer can be shut down when a user is not logged on. If this policy setting is enabled, the shutdown command is available on the Windows logon screen. It is recommended to disable this policy setting to restrict the ability to shut down the computer to users with credentials on the system.

inputs.name: Configure 'Audit object access'
inputs.hint: Configure 'Audit object access' (Not Scored)

inputs.name: Configure 'Audit directory service access'
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether to audit user access to an Active Directory object that has its own specified system access control list (SACL). If you define the Audit directory service access setting, you can specify whether to audit successes, failures, or not audit the event type at all.

inputs.name: Retain application log'
inputs.hint: This setting is the toggle setting to retain the application log and works in conjunction with the retention method for application logs setting.

inputs.name: Retain Security log
inputs.hint: This setting is the toggle setting to retain the security log and works in conjunction with the retention method for security logs setting.

inputs.name: Retain System log'
inputs.hint: This setting is the toggle setting to retain the system log and works in conjunction with the retention method for system logs setting.

inputs.name: Human Interface Device Access
inputs.hint: Enables generic input access to Human Interface Devices (HID), which activates and maintains the use of predefined hot buttons on keyboards, remote controls, and other multimedia devices. If this service is stopped, hot buttons controlled by this service will no longer function. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Distributed Link Tracking Client
inputs.hint: Maintains links between NTFS files within a computer or across computers in a network.

inputs.name: Telephony
inputs.hint: Provides Telephony API (TAPI) support for programs that control telephony devices on the local computer and, through the LAN, on servers that are also running the service.

inputs.name: Network Connections
inputs.hint: Manages objects in the Network and Dial-Up Connections folder, in which you can view both local area network and remote connections.

inputs.name: SNMP Trap
inputs.hint: Receives trap messages generated by local or remote Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) agents and forwards the messages to SNMP management programs running on this computer.

inputs.name: Distributed Transaction Coordinator
inputs.hint: Coordinates transactions that span multiple resource managers, such as databases, message queues, and file systems. If this service is stopped, these transactions will not occur. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: WMI Performance Adapter
inputs.hint: Provides performance library information from Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) providers to clients on the network. This service only runs when Performance Data Helper is activated.

inputs.name: Microsoft Software Shadow Copy Provider
inputs.hint: Manages software-based volume shadow copies taken by the Volume Shadow Copy service. If this service is stopped, software-based volume shadow copies cannot be managed. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Configure Workstation
inputs.hint: Creates and maintains client network connections to remote servers using the SMB protocol. If this service is stopped, these connections will be unavailable. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Remote Access Auto Connection Manager
inputs.hint: Creates a connection to a remote network whenever a program references a remote DNS or NetBIOS name or address.

inputs.name: Print Spooler
inputs.hint: Loads files to memory for later printing

inputs.name: Performance Logs & Alerts
inputs.hint: Performance Logs and Alerts Collects performance data from local or remote computers based on preconfigured schedule parameters, then writes the data to a log or triggers an alert. If this service is stopped, performance information will not be collected. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: TCP/IP NetBIOS Helper
inputs.hint: Provides support for the NetBIOS over TCP/IP (NetBT) service and NetBIOS name resolution for clients on the network, therefore enabling users to share files, print, and log on to the network. If this service is stopped, these functions might be unavailable. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Background Intelligent Transfer Service
inputs.hint: Transfers files in the background using idle network bandwidth. If the service is disabled, then any applications that depend on BITS, such as Windows Update or MSN Explorer, will be unable to automatically download programs and other information.

inputs.name: Netlogon'
inputs.hint: Maintains a secure channel between this computer and the domain controller for authenticating users and services. If this service is stopped, the computer may not authenticate users and services and the domain controller cannot register DNS records. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Remote Access Connection Manager
inputs.hint: Manages dial-up and virtual private network (VPN) connections from this computer to the Internet or other remote networks. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Network Location Awareness
inputs.hint: Collects and stores configuration information for the network and notifies programs when this information is modified. If this service is stopped, configuration information might be unavailable. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: DHCP Client
inputs.hint: Registers and updates IP addresses and DNS records for this computer. If this service is stopped, this computer will not receive dynamic IP addresses and DNS updates. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Plug and Play
inputs.hint: Enables a computer to recognize and adapt to hardware changes with little or no user input. Stopping or disabling this service will result in system instability.

inputs.name: COM+ System Application
inputs.hint: Manages the configuration and tracking of Component Object Model (COM)+-based components. If the service is stopped, most COM+-based components will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Windows Time
inputs.hint: Maintains date and time synchronization on all clients and servers in the network. If this service is stopped, date and time synchronization will be unavailable. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Smart Card
inputs.hint: Manages access to smart cards read by this computer. If this service is stopped, this computer will be unable to read smart cards. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: IPSEC Services
inputs.hint: Any service or application is a potential point of attack. Therefore, you should disable or remove any unneeded services or executable files in your environment. There are additional optional services available in Windows that are not installed during a default installation of the operating system. Depending on the version of Windows you can add these optional services to an existing computer through Add/Remove Programs in Control Panel, Programs and Features in Control Panel, Server Manager, or the Configure Your Server Wizard. Important: If you enable additional services, they may depend on other services. Add all of the services that are needed for a specific server role to the policy for the server role that it performs in your organization.

inputs.name: COM+ Event System
inputs.hint: Supports System Event Notification Service (SENS), which provides automatic distribution of events to subscribing Component Object Model (COM) components. If the service is stopped, SENS will close and will not be able to provide logon and logoff notifications. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Security Accounts Manager
inputs.hint: The startup of this service signals other services that the Security Accounts Manager (SAM) is ready to accept requests. Disabling this service will prevent other services in the system from being notified when the SAM is ready, which may in turn cause those services to fail to start correctly. This service should not be disabled.

inputs.name: DCOM Server Process Launcher
inputs.hint: Provides launch functionality for DCOM services.

inputs.name: Internet Connection Sharing (ICS)
inputs.hint: Provides network address translation, addressing, name resolution and/or intrusion prevention services for a home or small office network.

inputs.name: Application Management
inputs.hint: Processes installation, removal, and enumeration requests for software deployed through Group Policy. If the service is disabled, users will be unable to install, remove, or enumerate software deployed through Group Policy. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
inputs.hint: Provides a common interface and object model to access management information about operating system, devices, applications and services. If this service is stopped, most Windows-based software will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: System Event Notification Service
inputs.hint: Monitors system events and notifies subscribers to COM+ Event System of these events.

inputs.name: Volume Shadow Copy
inputs.hint: Manages and implements Volume Shadow Copies used for backup and other purposes. If this service is stopped, shadow copies will be unavailable for backup and the backup may fail. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Windows Audio
inputs.hint: Manages audio for Windows-based programs. If this service is stopped, audio devices and effects will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start

inputs.name: Cryptographic Services
inputs.hint: Provides four management services: Catalog Database Service, which confirms the signatures of Windows files and allows new programs to be installed; Protected Root Service, which adds and removes Trusted Root Certification Authority certificates from this computer; Automatic Root Certificate Update Service, which retrieves root certificates from Windows Update and enable scenarios such as SSL; and Key Service, which helps enroll this computer for certificates. If this service is stopped, these management services will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Windows Installer
inputs.hint: Adds, modifies, and removes applications provided as a Windows Installer (*.msi) package. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Server
inputs.hint: Supports file, print, and named-pipe sharing over the network for this computer. If this service is stopped, these functions will be unavailable. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start

inputs.name: Application Layer Gateway Service
inputs.hint: Provides support for 3rd party protocol plug-ins for Internet Connection Sharing

inputs.name: DNS Client
inputs.hint: The DNS Client service (dnscache) caches Domain Name System (DNS) names and registers the full computer name for this computer. If the service is stopped, DNS names will continue to be resolved. However, the results of DNS name queries will not be cached and the computer's name will not be registered. If the service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

inputs.name: Windows Firewall- Prohibit notifications
inputs.hint: Windows Firewall can display notifications to users when a program requests that Windows Firewall add the program to the program exceptions list. This situation occurs when programs attempt to open a port and are not allowed to do so because of current Windows Firewall rules. The Windows Firewall: Prohibit notifications setting determines whether these settings are shown to the users. If you configure this policy setting to Enabled, Windows Firewall prevents the display of these notifications. If you configure it to Disabled, Windows Firewall allows the display of these notifications.

inputs.name: Do not allow exceptions
inputs.hint: This policy setting caused Windows Firewall to block all unsolicited incoming messages. It overrides all other Windows Firewall settings that allow such messages. If you enable this policy setting in the Windows Firewall item in Control Panel, the Don't allow exceptions check box is selected and administrators cannot clear it.

inputs.name: Define inbound port exceptions
inputs.hint: Microsoft recommends that you avoid the use of this setting, unless required by your environment and your organization's business requirements. The Windows Firewall port exceptions list should be defined by Group Policy, which allows you to centrally manage and deploy your port exceptions and ensure that local administrators do not create less secure settings.

inputs.name: Define inbound program exceptions
inputs.hint: Microsoft recommends that you use this setting, if appropriate to your environment and your organization's business requirements, to help protect end user computers. Some applications may need to open and use network ports that are not typically allowed by Windows Firewall. The Windows Firewall: Define inbound program exceptions setting allows you to view and change the program exceptions list that is defined by Group Policy.

inputs.name: Allow local program exceptions
inputs.hint: Microsoft recommends that you avoid the use of this setting, unless required by your environment and your organization's business requirements. This policy setting controls whether administrators can use the Windows Firewall component in Control Panel to define a local program exceptions list.

inputs.name: Windows Firewall: Define inbound port exceptions
inputs.hint: Microsoft recommends that you avoid the use of this setting, unless required by your environment and your organization's business requirements; specifying allowed applications using the Define inbound program exceptions is usually a more secure approach. The Windows Firewall port exceptions list should be defined by Group Policy, which allows you to centrally manage and deploy your port exceptions and ensure that local administrators do not create less secure settings.

inputs.name: Windows Firewall: Define inbound program exceptions
inputs.hint: Some applications may need to open and use network ports that are not typically allowed by Windows Firewall. The Windows Firewall: Define inbound program exceptions setting allows you to view and change the program exceptions list that is defined by Group Policy.

inputs.name: Windows Firewall: Prohibit notifications
inputs.hint: Unless required by your environment and your organization's business requirements you may wish to avoid using this setting because the notifications can help users to understand why certain applications aren't working as expected. Windows Firewall can display notifications to users when a program requests that Windows Firewall add the program to the program exceptions list. This situation occurs when programs attempt to open a port and are not allowed to do so because of current Windows Firewall rules. The Windows Firewall: Prohibit notifications setting determines whether these settings are shown to the users.

inputs.name: Windows Firewall: Do not allow exceptions
inputs.hint: Microsoft recommends that you avoid the use of this setting, unless required by your environment and your organization's business requirements. This policy setting caused Windows Firewall to block all unsolicited incoming messages. It overrides all other Windows Firewall settings that allow such messages. If you enable this policy setting in the Windows Firewall item in Control Panel, the Don't allow exceptions check box is selected and administrators cannot clear it.

inputs.name: Do not process the legacy run list
inputs.hint: This policy setting causes the run list, which is a list of programs that Windows runs automatically when it starts, to be ignored. The customized run lists for Windows Vista are stored in the registry at the following locations: . HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run . HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run You can enable the Do not process the legacy run list setting to help prevent a malicious user from running a program each time Windows Vista starts, which could compromise data on the computer or cause other harm. When this policy setting is enabled, certain system programs are prevented from running, such as antivirus software, and software distribution and monitoring software. It is recommended to evaluate the threat level to your environment before you determine whether to use this policy setting for your organization.

inputs.name: Do not process the run once list
inputs.hint: This policy setting causes the run once list, which is the list of programs that Windows Vista runs automatically when it starts, to be ignored. This policy setting differs from the Do not process the legacy run list setting in that programs on this list will run once the next time the client computer restarts and an administrator logs on. Setup and installation programs are sometimes added to this list to complete installations after a client computer restarts. If you enable this policy setting, attackers generally cannot use the run once list to launch rogue applications, which was a common method of attack in the past. A malicious user can exploit the run once list to install a program that may compromise the security of Windows Vista based client computers, however since editing this list requires administrator privileges the importance of configuring this setting is not high.

inputs.name: Specify intranet Microsoft update service location
inputs.hint: This policy setting allows you to specify an intranet server to host updates from the Microsoft Update Web site. You can then use this update service location to automatically update computers on your network. The Automatic Updates client will search this service for updates that apply to the computers on your network. To use the Specify intranet Microsoft update service location setting, you must set two server name values: the server from which the Automatic Updates client detects and downloads updates, and the server to which updated workstations upload statistics. You can set both values to be the same server. If you enable the Specify intranet Microsoft update service location setting, the Automatic Updates client will connect to the specified intranet Microsoft update service server (instead of Windows Update) to search for and download updates. This configuration allows end users in your organization to avoid firewall issues, and provides you with an opportunity to test updates before you deploy them. If you disable or do not configure this policy setting, the Automatic Updates client will connect directly to the Windows Update site on the Internet (if Automatic Updates is not disabled by Group Policy or user preference).

inputs.name: Specify intranet Microsoft update service statistics location
inputs.hint: This policy setting allows you to specify an intranet server for statistics related to windows updates.

inputs.name: Allow users to connect remotely using Remote Desktop Services
inputs.hint: This policy setting allows you to control if users can connect to a computer using Terminal Services or Remote Desktop.

inputs.name: Prevent access to registry editing tools
inputs.hint: This policy setting disables the Windows registry editors Regedit.exe and Regedt32.exe.

inputs.name: Remove Security tab
inputs.hint: This policy setting disables the Security tab on the file and folder properties dialog boxes in Windows Explorer. If you enable this policy setting, users cannot access the Security tab after opening the Properties dialog box for all file system objects, including folders, files, shortcuts, and drives. Because the Security tab is inaccessible, users cannot change settings or view the list of users.

inputs.name: Remove CD Burning features
inputs.hint: This policy setting removes the built-in Windows Vista features that allow users to burn CDs through Windows Explorer. Windows Vista allows you to create and modify rewritable CDs if you have a read/write CD drive connected to your computer. This feature can be used to copy large amounts of data from a hard drive to a CD, which may then be removed from the computer. Note This policy setting does not prevent CDs from being modified orcreated by third-party applications that use a CD writer. Microsoft recommends the use of AppLocker or software restriction policies to block the creation or modification of CDs by third-party applications. Another way to prevent users from burning CDs is to remove the CD writers from the client computers in your environment or replace them with read-only CD drives.

inputs.name: LDAP server signing requirements
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) server requires LDAP clients to negotiate data signing.

inputs.name: Configure 'Add workstations to domain'
inputs.hint: This policy setting specifies which users can add computer workstations to a specific domain. For this policy setting to take effect, it must be assigned to the user as part of the Default Domain Controller Policy for the domain. A user who has been assigned this right can add up to 10 workstations to the domain.

inputs.name: Configure 'Create permanent shared objects'
inputs.hint: This user right is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace. However, components that run in kernel mode have this user right inherently. Therefore, it is typically not necessary to specifically assign this user right.

inputs.name: Configure 'Back up files and directories'
inputs.hint: This policy setting allows users to circumvent file and directory permissions to back up the system. This user right is enabled only when an application (such as NTBACKUP) attempts to access a file or directory through the NTFS file system backup application programming interface (API).

inputs.name: Configure 'Restore files and directories'
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines which users can bypass file, directory, registry, and other persistent object permissions when restoring backed up files and directories on computers that run Windows Vista in your environment.

inputs.name: Configure 'Create a token object'
inputs.hint: This policy setting allows a process to create an access token, which may provide elevated rights to access sensitive data.

inputs.name: Configure 'Allow log on through Terminal Services'
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines which users or groups have the right to log on as a Terminal Services client. Remote desktop users require this user right.

inputs.name: Configure 'Create global objects'
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether users can create global objects that are available to all sessions. Users can still create objects that are specific to their own session if they do not have this user right.

inputs.name: Configure 'Profile single process'
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines which users can use tools to monitor the performance of non-system processes. Typically, you do not need to configure this user right to use the Microsoft Management Console (MMC) Performance snap-in.

inputs.name: 'Restrict anonymous access to Named Pipes and Shares'
inputs.hint: When enabled, this policy setting restricts anonymous access to only those shares and pipes that are named in the Network access: Named pipes that can be accessed anonymously and Network access: Shares that can be accessed anonymously settings. This policy setting controls null session access to shares on your computers by adding RestrictNullSessAccess with the value 1 in the HKLM\System \CurrentControlSet\Services\LanManServer\Parameters registry key.

inputs.name: Use Certificate Rules
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether digital certificates are processed when software restriction policies are enabled and a user or process attempts to run software with an .exe file name extension. It enables or disables certificate rules (a type of software restriction policies rule).

inputs.name: Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer
inputs.hint: This policy setting determines whether users' private keys (such as their S-MIME keys) require a password to be used. If you configure this policy setting so that users must provide a password - distinct from their domain password - every time that they use a key, then it will be more difficult for an attacker to access locally stored keys, even an attacker who discovers logon passwords.

inputs.name: Syn attack protection level
inputs.hint: This entry appears as MSS: (SynAttackProtect) Syn attack protection level (protects against DoS) in the SCE. This entry causes TCP to adjust retransmission of SYN-ACKs. When you configure this entry, the overhead of  incomplete transmissions in a connect request (SYN) attack is reduced.

inputs.name: Force logoff when logon hours expire
inputs.hint: This policy setting, which determines whether to disconnect users who are connected to the local computer outside their user account's valid logon hours, affects the SMB component.

inputs.name: How many times unacknowledged data is retransmitted
inputs.hint: The registry value entry TCPMaxDataRetransmissions was added to the template file in the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip \Parameters\ registry key.

inputs.name: Shell Hardware Detection
inputs.hint: Any service or application is a potential point of attack. Therefore, you should disable or remove any unneeded services or executable files in your environment.

inputs.name: Logon Window Text
inputs.default:
You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.
By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:
-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.
-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.
-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.
-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.
-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.
